client_profile: Family of three looking to buy a house in Brussels. Budget is EUR 770,000–1,080,000. Priorities include cafes, parks, and quiet residential areas.
must_have: Access to parks and green spaces.
nice_to_have: Easy commute to the EU quarter.
Access to local markets and shops.
red_flags: High property taxes may affect budget.
Long commute times from outer areas.
contradictions: Quiet zones may lack cafe options.
Parks may increase distance to EU access.
Top schools might be in busier areas.

top_districts.name: Ixelles
why: Features numerous parks like Flagey Square, ideal for family outings and activities.
Diverse cafes create a vibrant brunch scene, attracting many international residents.
watch_out: Parking can be challenging due to local events and high traffic.

top_districts.name: Etterbeek
why: Close to Parc du Cinquantenaire offering greenery and picnic areas for families.
Attracts expats due to proximity to EU institutions and international schools.
watch_out: Prices can stretch the upper limit of your budget in desirable areas.

top_districts.name: Saint-Gilles
why: Known for its local cafes, providing a vibrant culture right in the neighborhood.
Access to public transport allows for easy commutes throughout Brussels.
watch_out: Higher noise levels may occur during weekends due to local nightlife.
